I agree with a lot of what you have to say, but I still contend that 'Every person (of a certain race, ethnicity, sex, gender, etc.) is a (insert negative characteristic here).' is a fundamentally bigoted statement that isn't very likely to win over minds among the diverse and politically varied class of people you are accusing of all possessing said negative characteristic. It's absolutely fair to argue that people who think a certain way or have a certain opinion share a negative characteristic associated with that manner of thinking or opinion, but to say that an entire class of people, by definition, must share some opinion, belief, or way of thinking, is wrong (both factually and morally). Not only is it wrong (on an interpersonal level, because it's blatantly insulting) to say 'all whites are racist' or 'all men are sexist', but even if making these (ironic) bigoted over-generalized accusations of bigotry leveled against an entire class of people don't harm those people the way other forms of bigotry do, you are still needlessly making political enemies out of people who may have been your allies (or would have at least been willing to have a civil discussion with you) had you simply chosen to state your case in a less accusatory and more respectful manner. When I hear 'All (people like you) are (bad in some way), my first instinct isn't to ask why you feel that way, my first instinct is to say 'No, we're not, and I know that because I'm not, you bigot.' and that's not really very productive if your objective is to have a productive conversation about the complex social and political issues surrounding race, ethnicity, sex, gender, etc. (though it is very productive if you are looking to start a conflict).

I think that that word is the lynchpin of the entire problem and disagreement here: the word 'racist' has *such* an extreme negative connotation, that using it when you talk about something 'everyone has' (innate racial bias) makes you come off very badly. No matter what adjective (slightly/minutely/a little bit) you put in front of racist, you are still using the word 'racist' to apparently describe every white person that exists, meaning you are applying the full weight of its negative connotation--and the consequences thereof upon the accused person's perceived character--to all of those people. That negates every qualifier, and turns it into an ad-hominem attack of a person's very moral stature. So, yeah, in a way it IS an entirely invalid claim--is indeed a racist claim--simply because you used the word 'racist.'
